projectCards.title: The Flow State
projectCards.problem: Traditional productivity timers interrupt focus with intrusive alerts and numerical countdowns, forcing users to monitor time directly instead of remaining immersed in deep work.
bulletPoints: Designed a generative biofeedback environment exploring how cognitive science and neuro-aesthetics can sustain deep work without explicit time tracking.
Implemented a linear node-injection algorithm that converts elapsed time into progressive visual density, encoding duration spatially instead of numerically.
Built multiple rendering modules (radial, fractal, rectilinear, glitch) that act as cognitive context primes, allowing users to match visual structure to task type.
Engineered a dual-oscillator Web Audio binaural engine that increases beat frequency along a controlled arousal curve aligned with the Yerkes–Dodson performance model.
Created a peripheral-awareness UI using translucency, blur, and motion to shift temporal monitoring to peripheral vision and reduce central executive load.
Integrated micro-reactive cursor physics that establishes ambient sensorimotor feedback, reinforcing engagement without gamification.

projectCards.dataTags: python pytorch ml hpc fmri neuroimaging regression analysis nlp cnn transformers multimodal data
projectCards.title: Predicting Neural Responses to Multimodal Stimuli
projectCards.problem: Predicting voxel-level brain activity during natural movie viewing requires integrating high-dimensional audiovisual and language features into models that generalize across unseen stimuli.
bulletPoints: Built a multimodal encoding pipeline in Python using PyTorch and nilearn to predict voxelwise fMRI responses to naturalistic movie stimuli.
Extracted synchronized video, audio, and language features using CNNs (AlexNet), transformer models (HuBERT), and NLP embeddings (RoBERTa).
Applied modality-specific PCA and regularized ridge regression to stabilize training on extremely high-dimensional neural data.
Ran large-scale hyperparameter sweeps on HPC clusters with Slurm scheduling and cross-validated model performance.
Integrated longer temporal context windows to improve generalization on held-out stimuli.
Conducted in the Computational Affective and Neuroscience Lab at UChicago under mentorship from Yuan Chang Leong and Monica Rosenberg, in collaboration with Olivia Sopala.
